data.title: Kinbaku · SM · 18
data.meta_description: Kinbaku · SM · 18-sai: Directed by Shûji Kataoka. With Shirô Shimomoto, Hiromi Saotome, Yutaka Ikejima, Ayu Kiyokawa. When the all-girl gang, The Bombers, kidnap a man to use as their personal sex slave, S&M Hunter accepts the mission to infiltrate The Bombers' hideout and show them the ropes.
data.text:
Welcome to the Torture Dungeon, a bordello specifically designed to cater for clientèle interested in exploring the world of sado-masochism. In this unique establishment, one can be master or servant, or even hire the services of Mr. S&M Hunter (Shirô Shimomoto), whose amazing abilities with rope make him master of all women (as one character remarks, "Even if Hulk Hogan were a girl, she'd be his slave!").

A completely bonkers piece of Pinku cinema unlike any I have seen before, S & M Hunter sees the titular rope-master employed by a gay man after his young lover is kidnapped for use as a sex slave by a tough, all female gang known as The Bombers. With some nifty knots and a couple of twangs on some carefully positioned ropes, S & M Hunter teaches The Bombers a few lessons in sexual pleasure that they'll never forget.

Less violent than many a Pinku movie, but just as twisted and blessed with a deliciously wicked sense of humour, S&M Hunter is an absolute riot and highly recommended for anyone looking for sleazy Japanese cinema without the extreme nastiness. The film's good-natured approach to its exploitative content is perfectly illustrated in the opening scene in which the bordello's owner describes the perversions available to his customer, sampling each one personally as he does so. This rich vein of subversive comic-book style humour is present throughout the whole film and makes the entire affair a hugely enjoyable experience.

Of course, that's not to say that S & M Hunter is going to appeal to your average, mainstream cinema-goer: with male and female rape, enemas, gratuitous Nazi imagery, topless arm-wrestling over knives, and excessive nun whipping, this film will still raise eyebrows amongst those not already desensitised to Asian excess.
